Daughter had a red side slider.  I found it when out duck hunting.  frozen in the ice of a small pond.  I put it in my hunting vest pocket and it revived in the pocket when hung in the garage.  We kept it for several years before releasing it in a small neighborhood pond.  It got so fat it couldn't pull its feet or legs inside its shell.  Painted the back of the shell before releasing it and could still recognize it several years later.  It along with the ducks would come to shore for bread handouts.

context:
OK, more questions than answers in this article.
How did these hatchlings get into the drainage system on the first place?
The female turtles lay up to 20 eggs per clutch on beaches and the hatchlings head for the ocean right away.
This means that this cardboard boxfull is the offspring of dozens of turtles, not just one poor shlemozel that was inadvertently washed into the drain system.
Anyone who really knows please educate us so that we can sleep at night.

replies.context: Diamondbacks are hatched in brackish, marshy areas near the shore and migrate to fresher waters. Mother terps lay eggs usually in 9 - 12 egg clutches. The hatchlings most likely migrated to the sewer system which was producing warmer air temps than was the surrounding area. The box full of hatchlings recovered was undoubtedly from several clutches that hatched in the same area at the same time.
